I don't know if it can be done considering how fragile Sars - CoV-2 is (it doesn't infect mice, and it's hard to grow in a lab), but fecal occult blood tests are common at - home tests where swabs and packaging are sent in the mail along with instructions on how to properly take the sample.
If such testing can be successfully done in the home, perhaps a similar one can be done for Sars - CoV-2 as well. Perhaps a tube of medium could be included to inoculate with the swab sample in order to encourage growth of the virus.

Then again, if it requires a cell to hijack, this might be impossible to do. A virus is not a bacterium, after all. And if cells are included in the medium, it makes the package a biohazard, and I think that either the post office won't deliver it or there are special regulations for doing so.

But if you can find Sars - CoV-2 in sewage, there's got to be something in sewage to sustain the virus.

Corona virus is also a political battle, and the new sewage tests may help win it.  So, one plan for that is to use the sewage test to limit lock downs to individual communities.  If your community sewage tests positive the residents are put on notice to stay in their yard.  Their phones indicate for them to be vigilant to symptoms.  A van can go around and apply daily testing.  Catching the virus before or at when symptoms appear will allow antivirals like Remdesivir to reduce the lockdown for most to a week, reduce hospitalizations, and reduce deaths.  Although, a week is an optimistic selling point, but it beats reaching herd immunity. The infected do not move from home.  A cell phone will provide doctor visits, moral support, and a pulse oxymeter to determine if hospitalization is needed.  Communities with mass transit are to provide n95 masks to prevent spread on the rail and washing stations, and here the Sewage tests public bath rooms to prove that the virus is spreading via bus and commuter rail.

This is the worst idea ever. I am amazed you created a video out of this nosense. Let me enumerated some cons of this idea:
1 - You are going to spend a lot of resources to design a new test on poop, but there are several other substances on wastewater plants that may affect this test, so basically you are going to design a test that is going to work (most likely) in a specific region. There are other variables here like the sewer lines. how they are connect? how far they are from the plant?.
2 - What is the gain in finding how much of covid is in the wastewater plant? Another useless metric. There are cities that already did mass tests, herewith the statistics of how many asymptomatic people vs "need treatment" peoples vs dead people is already known.
3 - People can have different concentration of the virus in their body. Are you going to pick an average to define which quantity concentration means one person got it?
